overview: A foundational adaptogenic herb in Ayurveda, clinically explored for stress resilience, sleep quality, cognition, inflammation, metabolic health, and musculoskeletal performance.

introduction.description: A drought-hardy Rasayana shrub used for vitality, longevity, recovery from illness and stress.

habitat.nativeRange: Dry and semi-arid Indian subcontinent, Middle East.
habitat.ecology: Dry stony or sandy loams; full sun.

cultivation.yieldNote: Root quality improved by proper drying.

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: Roots rich in withanolide glycosides.

overview: Known as the 'Queen of Herbs', Tulsi is revered for its spiritual significance and potent medicinal properties supporting respiratory health and stress response.

introduction.description: An aromatic perennial shrub widely grown in India for medicinal and religious purposes.

habitat.climate: Warm and humid; sensitive to frost.

cultivation.soil: Rich loam to poor laterite; good drainage essential.
cultivation.yieldNote: Herbage yield depends on nitrogen input.

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: Essential oil concentrated in glandular trichomes of leaves.

overview: The 'Golden Spice' of life, central to cooking and medicine in Asia, famous for its active compound Curcumin and potent anti-inflammatory effects.

introduction.description: A rhizomatous herbaceous perennial plant of the ginger family.

cultivation.inputs: Heavy feeder; requires mulching and organic matter.
cultivation.yieldNote: Curing (boiling and drying) essential for color and storage.

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: Curcuminoids concentrated in central rhizome.

overview: Often called the 'Village Pharmacy', Neem is a powerful detoxifier and antimicrobial agent used extensively in skin care and organic agriculture.

introduction.description: A fast-growing mahogany family tree, evergreen in most environments.

cultivation.soil: Thrives in almost any soil, including rocky and alkaline.

partsUsed.uses: Paste for skin, tea for detox.

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: Seeds highest in Azadirachtin; Leaves in Nimbin.

overview: One of the richest natural sources of Vitamin C, Amla is a Rasayana for rejuvenation, hair health, and digestive acidity regulation.

introduction.description: A deciduous tree producing sour, spherical, yellowish-green fruits.

cultivation.soil: Light to medium heavy soils; saline tolerant.

partsUsed.uses: Primary medicinal part; fresh, dried, or candied.

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: Fruit pulp contains the majority of bioactive tannins.

overview: A premier 'Medhya Rasayana' (brain tonic), Brahmi is renowned for enhancing memory, learning, and concentration while reducing anxiety.

introduction.description: A creeping, succulent herb that grows in wet, marshy areas.

habitat.nativeRange: Wetlands of India, Australia, Europe, Africa.
habitat.climate: Tropical to subtropical; high water requirement.

cultivation.yieldNote: Can be harvested multiple times a year.

partsUsed.uses: Used fresh in juice or dried in powders/ghritas.

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: Whole aerial parts are active.

overview: A universal remedy for digestive health and nausea, ginger warms the body and stimulates appetite and circulation.

introduction.description: A flowering plant whose rhizome, ginger root, is widely used as a spice and folk medicine.

habitat.climate: Requires high humidity and partial shade.

cultivation.soil: Friable sandy loam rich in humus.
cultivation.yieldNote: Higher fibre content in delayed harvest.

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: Shogaols increase upon drying/heating.

overview: Known as 'Amrita' (Immortality), Giloy is a supreme immunity booster and fever reducer, extensively used during viral outbreaks.

introduction.description: A large, deciduous climbing shrub with heart-shaped leaves.

habitat.ecology: Climbs on large trees (Neem-Giloy is prized).

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: Starch in stem contains immunomodulatory polysaccharides.

overview: A succulent plant offering cooling relief for skin burns and digestive soothing when consumed internally.

introduction.description: A succulent plant species of the genus Aloe. It grows wild in tropical climates.

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: Inner gel is water/polysaccharide; outer rind is bitter latex.

overview: Translating to 'She who possesses a hundred husbands', Shatavari is the premier female reproductive tonic in Ayurveda.

introduction.description: A woody climber with needle-like leaves and tuberous roots.

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: Roots are the storage organ for saponins.

overview: The 'Miracle Tree', incredibly nutrient-dense, providing proteins, vitamins, and minerals to fight malnutrition and inflammation.

introduction.description: A fast-growing, drought-resistant tree used for food and water purification.

cultivation.yieldNote: Drumsticks annual yield high in PKM varieties.

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: Leaves extremely high in micronutrients.

overview: A sweet root used to soothe throats, heal ulcers, and harmonize other herbal formulas.

introduction.description: A herbaceous perennial legume.

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: Glycyrrhizin is 50x sweeter than sugar.

overview: One of the three fruits in Triphala, known as the 'King of Medicines' in Tibet, used for detoxification and digestive regularity.

introduction.description: A deciduous tree native to South Asia.

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: High tannin content gives astringent taste.

overview: A brain and skin tonic, often confused with Brahmi, but distinct for its collagen-boosting and venous health properties.

introduction.description: A small herbaceous annual plant of the family Mackinlayaceae.

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: Leaves rich in active saponins.

overview: The premier heart tonic in Ayurveda, the bark of the Arjuna tree is used to strengthen cardiac muscle and regulate blood pressure.

introduction.description: A large, evergreen tree with buttressed trunk and smooth grey bark.

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: Inner bark is the medicinal source.

overview: A common kitchen spice with powerful applications for blood sugar control, lactation support, and testosterone support.

introduction.description: An annual plant in the family Fabaceae.

cultivation.yieldNote: Seeds harvested when pods turn yellow.

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: Seeds rich in mucilage and saponins.

overview: A warming spice derived from the inner bark of trees, supporting metabolic health and blood sugar balance.

introduction.description: True cinnamon is a small evergreen tree native to Sri Lanka.

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: Bark oil is cinnamaldehyde; Leaf oil is eugenol.

overview: The dried flower buds of the clove tree, possessing intense numbing and antimicrobial properties, famously used for toothaches.

introduction.description: An evergreen tree of the myrtle family.

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: Bud contains up to 20% essential oil.

overview: A hybrid mint famous for its cooling menthol content, used to soothe IBS, headaches, and respiratory congestion.

introduction.description: A hybrid species of mint, a cross between watermint and spearmint.

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: Oil glands on leaf surface.

overview: A vibrant flower used in refreshing teas, known for supporting blood pressure regulation and hair health.

introduction.description: A species of Hibiscus probably native to West Africa, used for the production of bast fibre and as an infusion.

chemicalConstituents.distributionSummary: Deep red calyces are richest in anthocyanins.
